metadata.abstract: The text explores the historical and geographical distribution of a sequence melody, examining its presence and variations across different regions, including Aquitaine, Normandy, and Italy. It discusses the possible origins of the melody, suggesting it may have traveled from Italy to France, and highlights the differences in melodic structure and textual assignments in various sources. The analysis suggests a potential Italian origin for the melody, with subsequent adaptations in French regions, and calls for further investigation into Italian sources to better understand its history.

segments.text: At least, it does not have a firm place in the oldest preserved repertories. It may have been older, but the sources start later. It was not known in East Francia. In Aquitaine, it seems to belong to a second chronological layer of sequences. So it's not part of the original layer in the oldest sequentiary, Paris 1240, but was added later with the text O Alma Trinitas Deitas and a melody titled Planctum. You can see some of the information about the Aquitanian sources on the first page of my hand.
It's absent from several of the well-known Aquitanian sources, and its assignment is variable. That is, its principal text in Aquitaine, O Alma Trinitas Deitas, is
assigned to Trinity, but occasionally appears elsewhere in the series, and its melody, when notated separately, does not form part of a firm group

around the Trinity feast. The same is true of its other text in Aquitaine, Oremus Omnes, which is assigned to Trinity in Paris 1118 but to all saints in its two other sources. One explanation might be that it was composed for Trinity but shares the instability of placement which dogs the chants for this feast in early medieval sources. In France, outside Aquitaine, it is likewise a relative late comer. In this area, its text is Eia Musa, always assigned to Pentecost. From the distribution of sources, it seems possible that Eia Musa is a Norman composition. It may have come to Normandy as part of the package imported from Saint-Bénigne at Dijon, for its melody turns up in the Cluny Gradual, Paris 1087, with the title Eia Musa. Only the melody is there, but it does have this title. A connection between Saint-Bénigne at Dijon and Cluny is quite plausible. It may be that at Cluny the piece was deprived of its text in accordance with Cluny's particular customs regarding the performance of sequences, and only the title then remained.

Salma Trinitas was unknown in Italy, and Eia Musa appears there only in Pistoia 121, but the melody was sung in Italy with the text Qui purgat animas. A further text, Ad est nunc preclara, was sung in Benevento, but this appears to be an exact contrafactum, reproducing exactly all the irregularities of melodic form to be found in Qui purgat animas. Since the state of the Italian sequenced repertory in the 10th century is largely unknown, we cannot say from the distribution of the surviving sources how long the melody had been known in Italy, before it first appears in manuscripts which are available to us. A few observations may help reconstruct the possible history of the melody. The principal question is, or at least the The question I was interested in, and this was stimulated by some remarks of Calvin Bauer, your paper on Captiva, you were wondering if this might not originally have been an Italian melody which traveled north and was texted in different ways in northern lands. When you mentioned this to me, I immediately thought, ah, perhaps here is another case, qui purgat animas, which this is why I'm now asking myself, was the melody imported into Italy, like so many others, there to receive a new text, or did it move from Italy across the Alps, and if so, how do the two French versions of the melody relate to each other and to a possible Italian origin?

Then, if you could turn to the musical example, my transcription of the melody. It goes over two pages. The three principal versions are labeled E, that's Eia Musa. O is O Alma Trinitas Deitas, or Oremos Omnes. And Q, Qui Purgat Animus. So E is this possible Norman, or at least North French version. O, in the middle, the Aquitanian version. And Q, the Italian version. The transcriptions obviously present a homogenized version based on more than one source. I apologize for this. But more detailed differences between the sources, which there certainly are, do not affect the broad lines of my demonstration today.

I should say that for qui purgat animas, I have not yet checked the versions in enough Italian sources. What you have here is the Beneventon version, and it may be that some important differences from this version are present in North Italian sources, which I haven't yet checked.

I've labeled the verses A for the opening phrase, the Alleluia phrase, and then 1 to 8 are the main verses, and Z is the conclusion. The opening, A, is more or less identical in Eya Musa and O Alma, and this is a first indication that these two sequences, the French ones, these two versions, are in general more similar to each other than to the Italian one. Verse 1 is odd because of the treatment of the little four-note figure, which I have labeled X.
da dee dee

The way I have set it out here, the way I've set out the verse here, makes it look relatively straightforward, with two repetitions of the complete verse in Ea Musa and Qui Purgat, but three in O Alma, so that for Ea Musa you have

but then an extra repetition in O Alma Trinitas Deitas. But Oremos Omnes, the other Aquitanian text, does not have this third repetition, and nor does the melody when notated as a sequencia in Paris 1240. But the scribes who notated the Aquitanian sources seem to have heard this four-note phrase as leading into the next phrase, not as a rounding-off cadential figure. So there is some confusion about the indications of repetition or lack of it in the sources. This is also the case with Ea Musa, but most of the scribes there seem quite clear in their minds about how the form of the melody goes. You see, what usually happens is, you can see it by the way the capital letters are placed in the text.
It goes like this. You have your open...
or something like that and then it goes the first verse la
And the next phrase is taken as belonging with the third phrase
And then it goes straight on. La.

So this little X phrase really belongs with what comes after, not with what has gone before. This is not so important for my discussion. I just want to point out it's a source of some confusion in the transmission.
Now, verse 3 has two extra phrases in O Alma Trinitas Deitas, but not in the other Aquitanian text, Oremus Omnes.

In verse 4, this is one of two verses where the Italian, qui purgat animas, has a varied repeat. I have to use first time bracket and second time bracket. It's not a very big difference, but you can see that qui purgat animas, verse 4, the first time it ends with a phrase which is split into two.
Amen.

This is in fact a repeat from earlier in the verse, but the second time it flows straight on, running those two phrases together. The differences between the three versions in the first phrase of this verse are worth noting. The French sequences have a slightly more characterful shape here. In fact, it echoes the verse tone for mode one responsories and cadences more emphatically on A. So in the French versions, at the beginning of verse four, the Italian is just a little less strongly characterized.
Verse 5, we move on to the last page there.
It appears in Aquitaine, in Oremus Omnes, but not in O Alma Trinitas Dei.

The melody alone, the sequentia, is recorded only in Paris, 1084, but it's somewhat different from the texted version of the melody. The texted version of the melody seems to anticipate the opening of verse 6. Let me just sing the version of the melody in Eia Musa, and for Oremus Omnes when it's, no, Oremus Omnes when it's texted. It goes, when the melody alone is notated without its text in Paris, 1084, it's rather different in outline, but this verse is not at all present in O Alma Trinitas Dei.
The opening of verse 6 is again more strongly characterized in the French sequences than the Italian one.
So that the French versions, E and O, are not Italian.

For the second phrase, Oremos Omnes avoids this striking accent. For the third phrase, it has the version of the other traditions. For the fourth phrase, it has the version of the Italian sequence. So it's a sort of in-between version. If you take O Alma Trinitas as the most strongly shaped version, and Qui Purgat Animus as the least strongly shaped version, then Oremos Omnes is in-between somehow.

Verse 7 is present only in the Italian sequence. It would be difficult to say which of the French versions had priority. E Amu. E Amuza is actually closer to Oremos Omnes than to O Alma Trinitas Deitas, with those extra or missing phrases in verses 1 and 5. Any of the French compositions is both more regular and more strongly characterized melodically than the Italian sequence. The French versions do not have the irregular varied repeats. Verse 6 has a stronger opening. In the Italian version, verses 4 and 6 are quite similar. And verse 7 echoes verse 5, both relatively shapeless, one might say. One might imagine a French cantor wanting to tighten up the melody, sharpen its profile a little, and cut out redundancies, so that verse 7 is cut out. It's too much like verse 5.

Arguing the other way around, one would have to say that the Italians had softened some of the edges of the French melody. So I prefer to think that the melody originated in Italy and traveled north. Whether or not we regard the Italian version of the melody as original, it shows some similarities with sequence melodies known to be Italian. Now, sequence verses generally very often approach cadences in a similar way, and the run-in may last a dozen notes or even longer, so that resemblances across several sequences are always quite common. But Cui Purgat is more repetitive than most melodies. Verses 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 all end with the same

but that is not unusual in verse 4 that cadence already ends phrase 2 followed by a shortened repetition and then a further shortened repetition if you look back at phrase 2 you can see what happens sorry at verse look back at verse 4 look back at verse 4 you have this already at the end of the second phrase
I'm looking at the Italian version now.
So progressive shortening.
Three phrases in verse 6 are similarly related.
The opening phrases lead into this material in various ways. In verse 2, we are below the finalis.
In verse 3, the upper fifth is reached, but the melody falls back from it.

Keep singing the Italian version here. Verse 4 establishes the upper fifth more firmly. And at this point, O Alma Trinitas maintains the upward momentum, going straight on to verse 6 and its upper C. Whereas verse 5 in Ea Musa and Oremos Omnes hang fire.

So there's something of a sort of upward progression here, which is most clearly evident in O Alma Trinitas. But the Italian version drops back to the finalis. And in verse 6, it seems not at all interested in moving onto higher ground, like the French version. And verse 7 then stays in this same. In range, the whole thing is much more restricted in range. Are there echoes here of the archaic Italian sequences labeled variation versus melodies by Kenneth Levy? Further investigations of the Italian repertory may help decide the issue. I felt at this point I'd only gone a very small step along a road which should include a more careful melodic analysis of the sequence melodies we know to be Italian.

As to the way north from Italy to France, if this is the right direction, then someone like William of Volpiano is as good a candidate as any for effecting the transfer. That is, it would come from north Italy with him to Dijon and then to Normandy, which is the place where most of the sources are situated. It would then be one of the accidents of history that a later cantor in the Norman tradition had the same idea. Madrid, 1941, the cantatorium from Catania in Sicily, is the Norman-Sicilian manuscript most closely connected by repertory to the sources from Norman monasteries. Of course, it includes Ea Musa and O Alma Trinitas Deitas, but it also picks up Qui Purgat Animas, no doubt from Benevento or Monte Cassino, so almost closing a circle whose tracing had begun a century and a half earlier.

Thank you very much, David. As Calvin said in between, there are a lot of, you just, this is a further bridge from the morning to the afternoon because we have to come back to all these questions like it's a thousand versions softening the edges, common origin, contextualization, criteria, and so on. But I think since we said it's one hour and we began a tiny bit late, we still would have some short questions.
Time for, yeah, yeah, Tom Giacomo Baro.
Thank you very much, David. I'm delighted to see Italy as a possible source of anything in the context of this conference.
Um, I...

I wanted to think for a minute, as you were speaking, about the manuscripts of Benevento, and it may be just this that Giacomo Barofio wanted to speak about. But thinking about the possible origins of this melody in Italy, it's likely that the Adestinunque Preclara for St. Bartholomew was composed at Benevento, I should think, since the relics of St. Bartholomew came to Benevento in 832 and left there at the millennium. So that at least gives a range of dates for the making of this contrafact. The two earliest manuscripts there, Benevento 38 and 40, which come from some point in the 11th century, rather nearer the beginning than the middle, I should think, contain Adestinunque Preclara but not Qui Purgat, probably because that part of the manuscript, the manuscript is missing in both witnesses. So we can't be certain whether Qui Purgat was there or not. But if Qui Purgat precedes the contrafact, if it is a contrafact, Adestinunque Preclara at Benevento, then it must have been there or been there, happily established there, when the relics of St. Bartholomew came to Benevento, which may help a little bit with the dating of this convent.
That's wonderful, Tom. I didn't know that Bartholomew had left Benevento so early. So that's absolutely crucial for the dating. Thank you.

Um...

I'm unclear about the significance of this cadence. I know that it's not so characteristic of the St. Gall German repertory. For Italy, I simply don't know. It is a slight question mark over the Italian origin because we don't have this type of sequence in the old variation versus melodies, which are the indisputably Italian early contribution to the sequence repertory.
